subject: add support for FreeIPA backend
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-02 23:56:02.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/commit/a7da51cff614ca845a365f48b79f8482b321f72e', 'message': 'add support for FreeIPA backend

This commit adds support for using FreeIPA as the DNS
backend.  This implementation uses the FreeIPA JSON
interface, doing HTTPS for security and Kerberos for
authentication.  The requirements are:
* python-kerberos 1.1 or later
* MIT kerberos5 version 1.11.3 or later
* A FreeIPA deployment, with an account that has access
to manage the DNS portion.  The admin@DOMAIN account
can be used for testing, but is not recommended for
production.  You must generate a keytab for this account
and Designate Central must have read access to
the keytab file.
* The CA cert file from FreeIPA (default /etc/ipa/ca.crt).

Specify backend_driver = ipa in the service:central config to
use the ipa backend.

The configuration parameters in the backend:ipa section are:
ipa_host - The hostname of the FreeIPA server (FQDN, for Kerberos)
ipa_port - default 80 - port number for web services listener
ipa_client_keytab - Kerberos client keytab file
ipa_ca_cert - HTTPS client CA certificate file
ipa_base_url - Base URL of web services server
- default https://%(hostname)s/ipa
ipa_json_url - IPA JSON RPC server
- default https://%(hostname)s/ipa/json
ipa_version - version of IPA RPC - default 2.65

There is a script that can be used to initially populate Designate
from FreeIPA called ipaextractor.py.  You use it like this:
1) Change Designate to use backend_driver = fake - this will allow it
to update its internal database but not the ipa backend which we are
importing from
2) run ipaextractor.py $ipa_host $ipa_base_url $ipa_client_keytab \
                       $ipa_ca_cert $designateurl
Where the ipa parameters are as described above, and $designateurl is
the designate API URL (https://localhost:9001/v1)

Change-Id: Ife76e5b72550f708fe672a0cc6e30e0c7450b917
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-04-03 17:13:14.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/designate/commit/1ba1c85ebca1edc4c3f61ac51fa2e001b4c14f69', 'message': 'add support for FreeIPA backend

This commit adds support for using FreeIPA as the DNS
backend.  This implementation uses the FreeIPA JSON
interface, doing HTTPS for security and Kerberos for
authentication.  The requirements are:
* python-kerberos 1.1 or later
* MIT kerberos5 version 1.11.3 or later
* A FreeIPA deployment, with an account that has access
to manage the DNS portion.  The admin@DOMAIN account
can be used for testing, but is not recommended for
production.  You must generate a keytab for this account
and Designate Central must have read access to
the keytab file.
* The CA cert file from FreeIPA (default /etc/ipa/ca.crt).

Specify backend_driver = ipa in the service:central config to
use the ipa backend.

The configuration parameters in the backend:ipa section are:
ipa_host - The hostname of the FreeIPA server (FQDN, for Kerberos)
ipa_port - default 80 - port number for web services listener
ipa_client_keytab - Kerberos client keytab file
ipa_ca_cert - HTTPS client CA certificate file
ipa_base_url - Base URL of web services server
- default https://%(hostname)s/ipa
ipa_json_url - IPA JSON RPC server
- default https://%(hostname)s/ipa/json
ipa_version - version of IPA RPC - default 2.65

There is a script that can be used to initially populate Designate
from FreeIPA called ipaextractor.py.  You use it like this:
1) Change Designate to use backend_driver = fake - this will allow it
to update its internal database but not the ipa backend which we are
importing from
2) run ipaextractor.py with no arguments will use the standard designate.conf
3) run ipaextractor.py file.conf will use the parameters from the given
config file
4) run ipaextractor.py and explicitly pass in the parameters
    ipaextractor.py $ipa_host $ipa_base_url $ipa_client_keytab \
                    $ipa_ca_cert $designateurl
Where the ipa parameters are as described above, and $designateurl is
the designate API URL (https://localhost:9001/v1)

Change-Id: Ife76e5b72550f708fe672a0cc6e30e0c7450b917

ipa_ca_cert - HTTPS client CA certificate file

- default $ipa_base_url/json

    ipaextractor.py [--config-file file.conf] \
        --backend:ipa-ipa-host hostname \
        ... other ipa options specified as --backend:ipa-optionname ...
        --service:ipa-api-base-uri=http://designateapihost:port
Where the ipa parameters are as described above
the default designate API URL is https://localhost:9001/
NOTE: if you want to specify both a config file (e.g. for common
options) but you want to override some of those via the command line,
you must specify --config-file file.conf first, before any other specfic
parameters you want to override.

commit_message:
add support for FreeIPA backend

This commit adds support for using FreeIPA as the DNS
backend.  This implementation uses the FreeIPA JSON
interface, doing HTTPS for security and Kerberos for
authentication.  The requirements are:
* python-kerberos 1.1 or later
* MIT kerberos5 version 1.11.3 or later
The above requirements are in the ipa-requirements.txt file used with pip
* A FreeIPA deployment, with an account that has access
to manage the DNS portion.  The admin@DOMAIN account
can be used for testing, but is not recommended for
production.  You must generate a keytab for this account
and Designate Central must have read access to
the keytab file.
* The CA cert file from FreeIPA (default /etc/ipa/ca.crt).

Specify backend_driver = ipa in the service:central config to
use the ipa backend.

The configuration parameters in the backend:ipa section are:
ipa_host - The hostname of the FreeIPA server (FQDN, for Kerberos)
ipa_port - default 443 - port number for web services listener
ipa_client_keytab - Kerberos client keytab file
ipa_ca_cert - HTTPS client CA certificate file
ipa_base_url - Base URL of web services server
- default https://$ipa_host/ipa
ipa_json_url - IPA JSON RPC server
- default $ipa_base_url/json
ipa_connect_retries - default 1 - the kerberos credentials will
expire periodically - the ipa backend will detect this and reauth
- ipa will attempt to retry the auth this many times before giving
up with an exception
ipa_force_ns_use - default False - IPA will attempt to resolve any
server specified in an SOA mname or NS record - setting this parameter
to True will force IPA to accept servers that cannot be resolved
ipa_version - version of IPA RPC - default 2.65
ipa_auth_driver_class - this is the domain + class name of the authentication
driver (subclass of requests.auth.AuthBase) that the ipa backend will use
to perform authentication against IPA
- default designate.backend.impl_ipa.auth.IPAAuth

There is a script that can be used to initially populate Designate
from FreeIPA called ipaextractor.py.  You use it like this:
1) Change Designate to use backend_driver = fake - this will allow it
to update its internal database but not the ipa backend which we are
importing from
2) run ipaextractor.py with no arguments will use the standard designate.conf
3) run ipaextractor.py --config-file file.conf will use the parameters from the given config file
4) run ipaextractor.py and explicitly pass in the parameters
    ipaextractor.py [--config-file file.conf] \
        --backend:ipa-ipa-host hostname \
        ... other ipa options specified as --backend:ipa-optionname ...
        --service:ipa-api-base-uri=http://designateapihost:port
Where the ipa parameters are as described above
the default designate API URL is https://localhost:9001/
NOTE: if you want to specify both a config file (e.g. for common
options) but you want to override some of those via the command line,
you must specify --config-file file.conf first, before any other specfic
parameters you want to override.

Change-Id: Ife76e5b72550f708fe672a0cc6e30e0c7450b917

added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright 2012 Managed I.T. # # Author: Kiall Mac Innes <kiall@managedit.ie> # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import unittest from designate.openstack.common import log as logging import designate.tests.test_central.test_service from designate import utils LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) class CentralServiceTestIPA(designate.tests.test_central. test_service.CentralServiceTest): test_config_file_name = "designate-ipa-test.conf" def start_service(self, svc_name, *args, **kw): """ override here so we can make sure central is set up correctly for live ipa testing """ if svc_name == 'central': self.config(backend_driver='ipa', group='service:central') # options in the test_config file can override the # defaults set elsewhere test_config = utils.find_config(self.test_config_file_name) self.CONF([], project='designate', default_config_files=test_config) return super(CentralServiceTestIPA, self).start_service(svc_name, *args, **kw) def setUp(self): super(CentralServiceTestIPA, self).setUp() # go directly through storage api to bypass tenant/policy checks save_all_tenants = self.admin_context.all_tenants self.admin_context.all_tenants = True self.startdomains = self.central_service.storage_api.\ find_domains(self.admin_context) LOG.debug("%s.setUp: startdomains %d" % (self.__class__, len(self.startdomains))) self.admin_context.all_tenants = save_all_tenants def tearDown(self): # delete domains # go directly through storage api to bypass tenant/policy checks self.admin_context.all_tenants = True domains = self.central_service.storage_api.\ find_domains(self.admin_context) LOG.debug("%s.tearDown: domains %d" % (self.__class__, len(self.startdomains))) for domain in domains: if domain in self.startdomains: continue # go directly to backend - front end domains will be # removed when the database fixture is reset self.central_service.backend.delete_domain(self.admin_context, domain) super(CentralServiceTestIPA, self).tearDown() @unittest.skip("this is currently broken in IPA") def test_idn_create_domain_over_tld(self): pass

commit_message:
Migration squashing

Newly generated alembic migration added. It replace whole stack of
migrations for previous releases which became not needed any more.

Change-Id: I6087a5dd56b19d96e2adb38be630decbbc439143
Closes-Bug: #1309126

subject: Fix a typo in compute/manager::remove_volume_connection()
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-22 18:23:02.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/compute/test_compute_mgr.py', 'nova/compute/manager.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1f349440f9f1dae44e765eb90c5c285fc71f1a54', 'message': 'Fix a typo in compute/manager::remove_volume_connection()

A typo made in the placement of a paren in a recent refactoring
resulted in definitely broken code. Unfortunately, this was not
in a tested path and so went unnoticed. This adds a test and fixes
the problem.

Change-Id: Id24169894ffda6da0301d1dc38b2f2bb29ebbd58
'}]
commit_message:
Fix a typo in compute/manager::remove_volume_connection()

A typo made in the placement of a paren in a recent refactoring
resulted in definitely broken code. Unfortunately, this was not
in a tested path and so went unnoticed. This adds a test and fixes
the problem.

Change-Id: Id24169894ffda6da0301d1dc38b2f2bb29ebbd58
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/63/89663/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: inst_obj = instance_obj.Instance._from_db_object( context, instance_obj.Instance(), instance) self._detach_volume(context, inst_obj, bdm)

commit_message:
Make db-sync and package import conditional

Move code to initial db-sync and package import under 'if' block
  to be executed only on primary controller node.

Closes-bug: 1314085

Change-Id: Iaf51ffbd7e50969da418067ed39e3915fe91834a

commit_message:
Don't translate debug level logs in nova.api

Our translation policy
(https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/LoggingStandards#Log_Translation) calls
for not translating debug level logs. This is to help prioritize log
translation. Furthermore translation has a performance overhead, even if
the log isn't used (since nova doesn't support lazy translation yet).

Change-Id: Ifb04bf41a47f485e8c668632d3a6ac51e02a16f8

commit_message:
Don't translate debug level logs in nova.volume

Our translation policy
(https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/LoggingStandards#Log_Translation) calls
for not translating debug level logs. This is to help prioritize log
translation. Furthermore translation has a performance overhead, even if
the log isn't used (since nova doesn't support lazy translation yet).

Change-Id: Ib529afea4d1696d8905e2d533803562130950d83

commit_message:
Run hacking and flake checks for real

Previous tox configuration didn't run any of hacking or flake8 checks. This
commit enables both. Here are details:
* Added hacking to test-requirements. It'll manage it's own dependencies -
  pep8, pyflakes, and flake8
* Enabled flake8
* Disabled a bunch of hacking and flake rules. They should be fixed in next
  dependend patches
* Add noqa where necessary
* Fix H902 Use the 'not in' operator for collection membership evaluation

Change-Id: If8b05ed64b028a128ebcd78722e57cb9023928a4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano-dashboard refs/changes/36/91036/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py26,py27,pep8skipsdist = Trueusedevelop = True install_command = pip install -U {opts} {packages}commands = flake8 {posargs}# F401 module imported but unused # H101 Use TODO(NAME) # H102 license header not found # H201 no 'except:' at least use 'except Exception:' # H202 assertRaises Exception too broad # H231 Python 3.x incompatible 'except x,y:' construct# H306 imports not in alphabetical order # H402 one line docstring needs punctuation # H404 multi line docstring should start without a leading new line # H501 Do not use locals() for string formatting # H702 Argument to _ must be just a string # H902 Use the 'not in' operator for collection membership evaluation ignore = F401,H101,H101,H201,H202,H231,H301,H302,H306,H402,H403,H404,H501,H702,H902
deleted_lines: envlist = py26,py27,pep8,pyflakesdeps = pep8==1.3.3 commands = pep8 --repeat --show-source muranodashboard setup.py# H201 no 'except:' at least use 'except Exception:' ignore = H301,H302,F403,H201

subject: debian: add systemd support
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-11 16:43:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder/commit/feb3e7d271da7407ff46090fa61dfdf313e72de6', 'message': 'debian: ability to use systemd

systemd or upstart are required for compatibility reason with
TripleO. This patch introduces the ability to use systemd over
sysv-init.

In this case, the user has to set DIB_DEBIAN_INIT_SYSTEM to
system.

On Wheezy, the backport is installed to get an up to date package.

Instead of upstart, the systemd package can be install on Wheezy
without a conflict on an existing essential package and will be
the default init system on Debian 8.

systemd or upstart are required for compatibility reasons with
TripleO. This patch introduces the ability to use systemd over
sysv-init.

In this case, the user has to include the debian-systemd in the
element list.

On Wheezy, systemd backport is installed to get an up to date package.

Instead of upstart, the systemd package can be installed on Wheezy
without a conflict on an existing essential package and will be
the default init system on Debian 8.

commit_message:
debian: add systemd support

This patch adds a debian-systemd element to get systemd support with
Debian.

A backport of systemd is used on Debian Wheezy.

Change-Id: I095c81b2c32844fccf940c97b79054923c25b8c2

commit_message:
debian: support upstart on Wheezy

Upstart cannot be installed by debootstrap on Wheezy because of a
conflict with sysvinit. sysvinit is flagged a being essential and
apt-get will refuse to remove it.
See: https://bugs.debian.org/668001

This patch uses another strategy. We install a standard sysvinit
Debian chroot with debootstrap and during a second step, we
replace sysvinit with the wanted init system.

Change-Id: I081c81b2c32874fccf940c97b79054923c25b8c2

commit_message:
Fill 'Latest Apps' section with recently deployed/uploaded Apps

Each App that was recently added to an Environment using Deploy/Quick
deploy button (actually, just pressing that button is enough) or
uploaded to catalog at Packages panel is added to Latest Apps list on
top of AppCatalog. To refresh that list with newly deployed App, on
final step Wizard is redirected to AppCatalog panel instead of simply
closing modal form. This fixes bug #1306579 as well.

That commit is dependent on https://review.openstack.org/#/c/90315/
and should be merged once that change gets into
python-muranoclient>=0.5.1.

Change-Id: Iefe2abb9efb5ae8cbe2d26809eb876eb0ecd5906
Closes-Bug: #1312213
Closes-Bug: #1306579

added_lines: import collectionsLATEST_APPS_QUEUE_LIMIT = 6def update_latest_apps(func): @functools.wraps(func) def __inner(request, **kwargs): apps = request.session.setdefault('latest_apps', collections.deque()) app_id = kwargs['app_id'] if app_id in apps: # move recent app to the beginning apps.remove(app_id) apps.appendleft(app_id) if len(apps) > LATEST_APPS_QUEUE_LIMIT: apps.pop() return func(request, **kwargs) return __inner @update_latest_apps @update_latest_apps ns_url = 'horizon:murano:catalog:index' return http.HttpResponseRedirect(url.reverse(ns_url)) pkgs, self.mappings = [], {} for pkg in pkgs: self.mappings[pkg.id] = pkg app_ids = self.request.session.get('latest_apps', []) context['latest_list'] = [self.mappings[app_id] for app_id in app_ids if app_id in self.mappings]

commit_message:
Adds a warning about the requirement to use Identity API 2.0

Object Storage is unaware of domains so ACLs cannot be enforced
when using Identity API 3.0

Change-Id: I6a1f8853e7cfcb5c4e8f789fa7fe8dfd6d3f7fdd
Closes-bug: 1299146
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/25/90825/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <para>Though you can install OpenStack Object Storage for development or testing purposes on one server, a multiple-server installation enables the high availability and redundancy you want in a production distributed object storage system.</para> <para>To perform a single-node installation for development purposes from source code, use the Swift All In One instructions (Ubuntu) or DevStack (multiple distros). See <link >http://swift.openstack.org/development_saio.html</link> for manual instructions or <link xlink:href="http://devstack.org" >http://devstack.org</link> for all-in-one including authentication with the Identity Service (keystone).</para> <warning> <para>In this guide we recommend installing and configuring the Identity service so that it implements Identity API v2.0. The Object Storage service is unaware of domains when implementing Access Control Lists (ACLs), so you must use the v2.0 API to avoid having identical user names in different domains, which would enable two users to access the same objects.</para> </warning> <para>Have a copy of the operating system installation media available if you are installing on a new server.</para> <para>These steps assume you have set up repositories for packages for your operating system as shown in <link linkend="basics-packages" >OpenStack Packages</link>.</para> <para>This document demonstrates how to install a cluster by using the following types of nodes:</para> processes. The proxy server proxies requests to the appropriate storage nodes.</para> <para>Five storage nodes that run the swift-account-server, swift-container-server, and swift-object-server processes which control storage of the account databases, the container databases, as well as the actual stored <para>Fewer storage nodes can be used initially, but a minimum of five is recommended for a production cluster.</para> Storage Service can use to authenticate with the Identity Service. Choose a password and specify an email address for the <literal>swift</literal> user. Use the <literal>service</literal> tenant and give the user the <literal>admin</literal> role:</para> <para>Create a service entry for the Object Storage Service:</para> <note> <para>The service ID is randomly generated and is different from the one shown here.</para> </note> <para>Specify an API endpoint for the Object Storage Service by using the returned service ID. When you specify an endpoint, you provide URLs for the public API, internal API, and admin API. In this guide, the <literal>controller</literal> host name is used:</para> <para>Create the configuration directory on all nodes:</para> <para>Create <filename>/etc/swift/swift.conf</filename> on all nodes:</para> <para>The suffix value in <filename>/etc/swift/swift.conf</filename> should be set to some random string of text to be used as a salt when hashing to determine mappings in the ring. This file must be the same on every node in the cluster!</para> <para>Next, set up your storage nodes and proxy node. This example uses the Identity Service for the common authentication piece.</para>
deleted_lines: <para>Though you can install OpenStack Object Storage for development or testing purposes on one server, a multiple-server installation enables the high availability and redundancy you want in a production distributed object storage system.</para> <para>To perform a single-node installation for development purposes from source code, use the Swift All In One instructions (Ubuntu) or DevStack (multiple distros). See <link >http://swift.openstack.org/development_saio.html</link> for manual instructions or <link xlink:href="http://devstack.org" >http://devstack.org</link> for all-in-one including authentication with the Identity Service (keystone).</para> <para>Have a copy of the operating system installation media available if you are installing on a new server.</para> <para>These steps assume you have set up repositories for packages for your operating system as shown in <link linkend="basics-packages">OpenStack Packages</link>.</para> <para>This document demonstrates how to install a cluster by using the following types of nodes:</para> processes. The proxy server proxies requests to the appropriate storage nodes.</para> <para>Five storage nodes that run the swift-account-server, swift-container-server, and swift-object-server processes which control storage of the account databases, the container databases, as well as the actual stored <para>Fewer storage nodes can be used initially, but a minimum of five is recommended for a production cluster.</para> Storage Service can use to authenticate with the Identity Service. Choose a password and specify an email address for the <literal>swift</literal> user. Use the <literal>service</literal> tenant and give the user the <literal>admin</literal> role:</para> <para>Create a service entry for the Object Storage Service:</para> <note><para>The service ID is randomly generated and is different from the one shown here.</para></note> <para>Specify an API endpoint for the Object Storage Service by using the returned service ID. When you specify an endpoint, you provide URLs for the public API, internal API, and admin API. In this guide, the <literal>controller</literal> host name is used:</para> <para>Create the configuration directory on all nodes:</para> <para>Create <filename>/etc/swift/swift.conf</filename> on all nodes:</para> <para>The suffix value in <filename>/etc/swift/swift.conf</filename> should be set to some random string of text to be used as a salt when hashing to determine mappings in the ring. This file must be the same on every node in the cluster!</para> <para>Next, set up your storage nodes and proxy node. This example uses the Identity Service for the common authentication piece.</para>

commit_message:
Using attribute schema for building documentation

At now attributes have their own Schema class with support_status
option. This information should be displayed in documentation.
Current change makes possible to use new schema for building
documentation.

Change-Id: I40af79b57defb99c7b131583b5fedfd3a67968d1
Closes-Bug: #1306383
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/03/86803/9 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from heat.engine import attributes self.attrs_schemata = attributes.schemata( self.resource_class.attributes_schema) if not self.attrs_schemata: for prop_key, prop in sorted(self.attrs_schemata.items()): description = prop.description if prop.support_status.status != support.SUPPORTED: para = nodes.inline( '', _('%(status)s - %(message)s') % prop.support_status.to_dict()) warning = nodes.note('', para) definition.append(warning)
deleted_lines: schema = self.resource_class.attributes_schema if not schema: for prop_key in sorted(schema.keys()): description = schema[prop_key]

commit_message:
Stub integration tests for vanilla, vanilla2 and hdp plugins

Partial-implements: blueprint cli-integration-tests
Change-Id: Ifa6dfccc7081c97cfa2507eb1bba15eb7732aa5b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-saharaclient refs/changes/71/89371/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright (c) 2014 Red Hat Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); # you may not use this file except in compliance with the License. # You may obtain a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, # WITHOUT WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or # implied. # See the License for the specific language governing permissions and # limitations under the License. import logging import shlex import six import subprocess from saharaclient.tests.integration.configs import config as cfg cfg = cfg.ITConfig() LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) # This is modeled after the client interface in tempest cli tests.2 class CommandBase(object): def sahara(self, action, flags='', params='', fail_ok=False): return self.cmd_with_bypass('sahara', action, flags, params, fail_ok) def cmd_with_bypass(self, cmd, action, flags='', params='', fail_ok=False): if cfg.common_config['BYPASS_URL']: bypass = '--bypass-url %s' % cfg.common_config['BYPASS_URL'] flags = bypass + ' ' + flags return self.cmd_with_auth(cmd, action, flags, params, fail_ok) def cmd_with_auth(self, cmd, action, flags='', params='', fail_ok=False): """Executes given command with auth attributes appended.""" creds = ('--os-username %s --os-tenant-name %s --os-password %s ' '--os-auth-url %s ' % (cfg.common_config['OS_USERNAME'], cfg.common_config['OS_TENANT_NAME'], cfg.common_config['OS_PASSWORD'], cfg.common_config['OS_AUTH_URL'])) flags = creds + ' ' + flags return self.cmd(cmd, action, flags, params, fail_ok) def cmd(self, cmd, action, flags='', params='', fail_ok=False, merge_stderr=False): """Executes specified command for the given action.""" cmd = ' '.join([cmd, flags, action, params]) LOG.info("running: '%s'" % cmd) cmd_str = cmd cmd = shlex.split(cmd) result = '' result_err = '' try: stdout = subprocess.PIPE stderr = subprocess.STDOUT if merge_stderr else subprocess.PIPE proc = subprocess.Popen( cmd, stdout=stdout, stderr=stderr) result, result_err = proc.communicate() if not fail_ok and proc.returncode != 0: raise CommandFailed(proc.returncode, cmd, result) finally: LOG.debug('output of %s:\n%s' % (cmd_str, result)) if not merge_stderr and result_err: LOG.debug('error output of %s:\n%s' % (cmd_str, result_err)) return result class CommandFailed(subprocess.CalledProcessError): # adds output attribute for python2.6 def __init__(self, returncode, cmd, output): super(CommandFailed, self).__init__(returncode, cmd) self.output = output class CLICommands(CommandBase): def register_image(self, image_id, username='', description=''): params = '--id %s' % image_id if username: params += ' --username %s' % username if description: params += ' --description %s' % description return self.sahara('image-register', params=params) def unregister_image(self, id): params = '--id %s' % id return self.sahara('image-unregister', params=params) def tag_image(self, id, tag): params = '--id %s --tag %s' % (id, tag) return self.sahara('image-add-tag', params=params) def node_group_template_create(self, filename): params = '--json %s' % filename return self.sahara('node-group-template-create', params=params) def node_group_template_delete(self, id): params = '--id %s' % id return self.sahara('node-group-template-delete', params=params) def cluster_template_create(self, filename): params = '--json %s' % filename return self.sahara('cluster-template-create', params=params) def cluster_template_delete(self, id): params = '--id %s' % id return self.sahara('cluster-template-delete', params=params) def cluster_create(self, filename): params = '--json %s' % filename return self.sahara('cluster-create', params=params) def cluster_delete(self, id): params = '--id %s' % id return self.sahara('cluster-delete', params=params) def job_binary_create(self, name, url, desc='', username='', password=''): params = '--name %s --url %s' % (name, url) if desc: params += ' --description %s' % desc if username: params += ' --user %s' % username if password: params += ' --password %s' % password return self.sahara('job-binary-create', params=params) def job_binary_delete(self, id): params = '--id %s' % id return self.sahara('job-binary-delete', params=params) def job_binary_data_create(self, fname): params = '--file %s' % fname return self.sahara('job-binary-data-create', params=params) def job_binary_data_delete(self, id): params = '--id %s' % id return self.sahara('job-binary-data-delete', params=params) def job_template_create(self, name, jobtype, main='', lib=''): params = '--name %s --type %s' % (name, jobtype) if main: params += ' --main %s' % main if lib: params += ' --lib %s' % lib return self.sahara('job-template-create', params=params) def job_template_delete(self, id): params = '--id %s' % id return self.sahara('job-template-delete', params=params) def job_create(self, job_id, cluster_id, input_id='', output_id='', job_params=None, args=None, configs=None): params = '--job-template %s --cluster %s' % (job_id, cluster_id) if input_id: params += ' --input-data %s' % input_id if output_id: params += ' --output-data %s' % output_id if job_params: for k, v in six.iteritems(params): params += ' --param %s=%s' % (k, v) if args: for arg in args: params += ' --arg %s' % arg if configs: for k, v in six.iteritems(configs): params += ' --config %s=%s' % (k, v) return self.sahara('job-create', params=params) def job_delete(self, id): params = '--id %s' % id return self.sahara('job-delete', params=params) def data_source_create(self, name, datatype, url, desc='', username='', password=''): params = '--name %s --type %s --url %s' % (name, datatype, url) if desc: params += ' --description %s' % desc if username: params += ' --user %s' % username if password: params += ' --password %s' % password return self.sahara('data-source-create', params=params) def data_source_delete(self, id): params = '--id %s' % id return self.sahara('data-source-delete', params=params)

commit_message:
Fixed floating IP logic in PLUMgrid plugin

  * Fixed associate and disassociate
    floating IP logic
  * Added unit tests

Change-Id: I310f5550bca1c9015cbda3e0338eb90a36dc96f1
Closes-Bug: 1298495
(cherry picked from commit 9f8cb33557ecc7c0a832610e913a56a8b8e6c524)

added_lines: class TestDisassociateFloatingIP(PLUMgridPluginV2TestCase): def test_disassociate_floating_ip(self): port_id = "abcdefgh" tenant_id = "94eb42de4e331" fip_net_id = "b843d18245678" fip_addr = "10.0.3.44" fip_id = "e623679734051" fip = {"router_id": "94eb42de4e331", "tenant_id": tenant_id, "floating_network_id": fip_net_id, "fixed_ip_address": "192.168.8.2", "floating_ip_address": fip_addr, "port_id": port_id, "id": fip_id} plumlib = importutils.import_object(PLUM_DRIVER) fip_res = plumlib.disassociate_floatingips(fip, port_id) self.assertEqual(fip_res["id"], fip_id) self.assertEqual(fip_res["floating_ip_address"], fip_addr) self.assertEqual(fip_res["floating_network_id"], fip_net_id)

commit_message:
Add disabled kwarg to service_get_all_by_topic

service_get_all_by_topic disabled kwarg allows results to include
where disabled is True or False or both.

Updated code where service_get_all_by_topic is used to make use of
disabled kwarg instead of filtering afterwards.

Removed logging of disabled services in host_manager.

Closes-Bug: #1285673
Change-Id: I748461e64acd4e9563c4016781c5e1d4b116dac8

This patch set will help us make a painless transition from sahara-api

commit_message:
Add sahara-all binary

In the nearest future we are going to split current sahara-api process into
two: sahara-api and sahara-engine. The new process sahara-all will replace
the old sahara-api in that it will run standalone Sahara all-in-one, which
does not require running several different processes.

This patch set will help us make a painless transition from sahara-api
to sahara-all in our CI. The plan is:
 * merge current patch set, which just adds sahara-all alias to
   sahara-api
 * change CI to run sahara-all instead of sahara-api
 * merge patch set which splits sahara-api and sahara-engine

Change-Id: I4fa68364b756c803a3fa8a0b92813785636ea13c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/sahara refs/changes/20/90720/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Make shotgun to work inside containers

Previously, the config is generated with assumption that master/postgres
node is localhost. Since now, the addresses are getting from external
settings file (/etc/nailgun/settings.yaml).

Closes-Bug: 1312620
Closes-Bug: 1313839

Change-Id: If041cae5b06fb12e1085107147f75922a066ae37

commit_message:
Improve the query_to_kwargs method

Currently, the timestamp in query fields is not unified.
start_timestamp/end_timestamp and start/end shouldn't be supported in some
APIs, this patch improve the query_to_kwargs method to forbid these in
query field.
part2: transform timestamp to db function's params.

Change-Id: I0ba30e4523f47250daa27b948958cc3bc3798e08
Closes-bug: #1291171
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/36/90636/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: valid_keys = set(inspect.getargspec(db_func)[0]) timestamp_fields = {'end', 'start', 'end_timestamp', 'start_timestamp'} if valid_keys & timestamp_fields: valid_keys = valid_keys - timestamp_fields valid_keys.add('timestamp') valid_keys.add('search_offset') valid_keys = valid_keys - set(internal_keys) return valid_keys valid_keys = _validate_query(query, db_func, internal_keys=internal_keys, allow_timestamps=allow_timestamps) func_keys = set(inspect.getargspec(db_func)[0]) supported_start_fieds = {'start', 'start_timestamp','start_time'} if func_keys & supported_start_fieds: func_start = list(func_keys & supported_start_fieds)[0] supported_end_fieds = {'end', 'end_timestamp', 'end_time'} if func_keys & supported_end_fieds: func_end = list(func_keys & supported_end_fieds)[0] kwargs[func_start] = q_ts['query_start'] kwargs[func_end] = q_ts['query_end'] kwargs['start_timestamp_op'] = stamp.get('start_timestamp_op') kwargs['end_timestamp_op'] = stamp.get('end_timestamp_op') def _parse_timestamp(timestamp, offset, type): if not timestamp: return None, None try: iso_timestamp = timeutils.parse_isotime(timestamp) iso_timestamp = iso_timestamp.replace(tzinfo=None) except ValueError as e: raise wsme.exc.InvalidInput('timestamp', timestamp) if type == 'start': query_start = (iso_timestamp - datetime.timedelta(minutes=offset)) return iso_timestamp, query_start else: query_end = (iso_timestamp + datetime.timedelta(minutes=offset)) return iso_timestamp, query_end start_timestamp, query_start = _parse_timestamp(start_timestamp, search_offset, 'start') end_timestamp, query_end = _parse_timestamp(end_timestamp, search_offset, 'end')
deleted_lines: valid_keys = inspect.getargspec(db_func)[0] valid_keys = set(valid_keys) - set(internal_keys) _validate_query(query, db_func, internal_keys=internal_keys, allow_timestamps=allow_timestamps) internal_keys.append('self') valid_keys = set(inspect.getargspec(db_func)[0]) - set(internal_keys) if 'start' in valid_keys: kwargs['start'] = q_ts['query_start'] kwargs['end'] = q_ts['query_end'] elif 'start_timestamp' in valid_keys: kwargs['start_timestamp'] = q_ts['query_start'] kwargs['end_timestamp'] = q_ts['query_end'] if 'start_timestamp_op' in stamp: kwargs['start_timestamp_op'] = stamp['start_timestamp_op'] if 'end_timestamp_op' in stamp: kwargs['end_timestamp_op'] = stamp['end_timestamp_op'] if start_timestamp: start_timestamp = timeutils.parse_isotime(start_timestamp) start_timestamp = start_timestamp.replace(tzinfo=None) query_start = (start_timestamp - datetime.timedelta(minutes=search_offset)) else: query_start = None if end_timestamp: end_timestamp = timeutils.parse_isotime(end_timestamp) end_timestamp = end_timestamp.replace(tzinfo=None) query_end = end_timestamp + datetime.timedelta(minutes=search_offset) else: query_end = None

commit_message:
Return caching to AppCatalog

Cache Application logo and dynamic_ui markup on local file-system
using `cache.with_cache` decorator. Objects are cached using cPickle
module to allow the function cached by `cache.with_cache` to return
arbitrary objects, not only string or buffer.

Change-Id: Ia0d89b38be1f0776d6e910e3126d89c978db0f10
Implements: blueprint ui-local-cache
Partial-Bug: #1312251

See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import logging import os import time from muranodashboard.environments.consts import IMAGE_CACHE_DIR LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) CHUNK_SIZE = 2048 if not os.path.exists(IMAGE_CACHE_DIR): os.mkdir(IMAGE_CACHE_DIR) LOG.info('Creating image cache directory located at {dir}'. format(dir=IMAGE_CACHE_DIR)) LOG.info('Using image cache directory located at {dir}'. format(dir=IMAGE_CACHE_DIR)) def load_from_file(file_name): if os.path.exists(file_name): data = [] with open(file_name, 'rb') as f: buf = f.read(CHUNK_SIZE) while buf: data.append(buf) buf = f.read(CHUNK_SIZE) return data else: return None class ImageCache(object): """ Cache is a map which keeps the filenames for images """ #TODO (gokrokve) define this as a config parameter max_cached_count = 120 #TODO (gokrokve) define this as a config parameter cache_age = 120 def __init__(self, **kwargs): self.cache = {} self.last_clean = time.time() def get_entry(self, name): entry = self.cache.get(name, None) if entry is None: return else: LOG.debug("Cached entry: %s" % name) data = load_from_file(entry['file_name']) entry['last_updated'] = time.time() return data def put_cache(self, name, file_name): self.cache[name] = { 'file_name': file_name, 'last_updated': time.time() } def clean(self): LOG.debug("Clean cache entries.") current_time = time.time() for k, v in self.cache.iteritems(): if current_time - v['last_updated'] > self.cache_age: LOG.debug("Remove old entry %s" % k) self.cache.pop(k)

commit_message:
Fix eventlet monkey patch and threadlocal usage

* according to the docs
  http://eventlet.net/doc/patching.html#eventlet.patcher.monkey_patch
  the monkey patching should be done as early as possible. It looks like
  this requirement wasn't satisfied before and probably it was the
  reason for several issues with threading;
* all tests are now using base savanna tests with test context available
  to use;
* threadlocal usage was fixed by using monkey patched threadlocal in the
  correct way - as a global storage;
* volumes test was fixed to use test thread group that executes all
  stuff consecutive, helper added to the base tests class.
* sahara.context now uses only 'greened' system modules. That is needed
  for context_test to pass, as it requires 'green' context and we don't
  do monkey patching in tests

Co-Authored-By: Dmitry Mescheryakov <dmescheryakov@mirantis.com>

Change-Id: I3d31ceb4b9c867d4875bfca948beb52260ee8957

added_lines: return hasattr(_CTXS, 'curr_ctx') return _CTXS.curr_ctx if not new_ctx and hasattr(_CTXS, 'curr_ctx'): del _CTXS.curr_ctx _CTXS.curr_ctx = new_ctx
deleted_lines: from eventlet import corolocal_CTXS._curr_ctxs = {} ident = corolocal.get_ident() return ident in _CTXS._curr_ctxs and _CTXS._curr_ctxs[ident] return _CTXS._curr_ctxs[corolocal.get_ident()] ident = corolocal.get_ident() if not new_ctx and ident in _CTXS._curr_ctxs: del _CTXS._curr_ctxs[ident] _CTXS._curr_ctxs[ident] = new_ctx

commit_message:
Deprecate instance_get_active_by_window_joined() from conductor

This deprecates the instance_get_active_by_window_joined() method
from conductor which is no longer used.

Related to blueprint compute-manager-objects-juno

Change-Id: Ia9ce0cf49180806da64cc034ad12ddf2b3f1c424

commit_message:
Added keystone v3 support

This patch enables keystone v3 token auth and ec2 auth.
Also it enables keystone v3 support in tempest.
Tempest code should be reviewed.

Change-Id: I421c6c16216d7a0cc9902c7351d504359a600adf
Implements: blueprint multi-tenancy-enforcement

commit_message:
Made template for service VM unique using generic driver

Without this commit, using multibackend installation with more than
one generic driver, for all of them will be used only one service VM,
in case of default value for template of service VM.
It can cause ssh connection error to service VM by backend, that
didn't create it and has different username or password.

Closes-Bug: #1314296
Change-Id: I9d307ca61e8306a301de403738296823d25a2a62

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-18 15:05:45.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/commit/c527bc666ca78b2fecdabde0a268a77d32f17244', 'message': 'Fix networking on the control node after reboot

When the control node is rebooted, ethX interface receives
configuration via DHCP, but still is a port of an OVS bridge.
The bridge itself seems to be configured correctly, but there
are no flows in ovs-dpctl output, so the networking is basically
down until you do os-refresh-config.

This is mostly covered by the following commits:
  - t-i-e: Ib775598d3bdd6f1ccecb283f47d10b92aaf0bd35
  - d-i-b: I3166951c6fbb2faec53ffc339edd2fd0c3512300

by making bridge/interface configuration persistent by the means of
network configuration files.

There is still one edge case left. When the node is PXE booted,
"ip=..." command line is supplied to the kernel, and the latter
configures the network interface. On ubuntu this leads to a situation
when the OVS bridge is configured correctly and receives network
configuration over DHCP, but ethX still has an IP address, so
there are two routes to 192.0.2.0 network.

The solution is to remove the ip address from ethX interface right
before the bridge is up. Curiously, this is only needed for Ubuntu.

Closes-Bug: #1304424

Change-Id: Idd6b5b3f98d00286aad512a3b55dfb7fa75a5fb8
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-04-29 19:10:28.000000000', 'files': ['elements/network-utils/bin/ensure-bridge'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements/commit/78f8e61d4bb19593c50c239515153b627d6fb5cc', 'message': 'Fix networking on the control node after reboot

when the OVS bridge is configured correctly and receives network
configuration over DHCP, but ethX still has an IP address, so

The solution is to remove the ip address from ethX interface right
before the bridge is up. Curiously, this is only needed for Ubuntu.

Closes-Bug: #1304424

Change-Id: Idd6b5b3f98d00286aad512a3b55dfb7fa75a5fb8

commit_message:
Fix networking on the control node after reboot

When the control node is rebooted, ethX interface receives
configuration via DHCP, but still is a port of an OVS bridge.
The bridge itself seems to be configured correctly, but there
are no flows in ovs-dpctl output, so the networking is basically
down until you do os-refresh-config.

This is mostly covered by the following commits:
  - t-i-e: Ib775598d3bdd6f1ccecb283f47d10b92aaf0bd35
  - d-i-b: I3166951c6fbb2faec53ffc339edd2fd0c3512300

by making bridge/interface configuration persistent by the means of
network configuration files.

There is still one edge case left. When the node is PXE booted,
"ip=..." command line is supplied to the kernel, and the latter
configures the network interface. On ubuntu this leads to a situation
when the OVS bridge is configured correctly and receives network
configuration over DHCP, but ethX still has an IP address, so
there are two routes to 192.0.2.0 network.

The solution is to remove the ip address from ethX interface right
before the bridge is up. Curiously, this is only needed for Ubuntu.

Closes-Bug: #1304424

Change-Id: Idd6b5b3f98d00286aad512a3b55dfb7fa75a5fb8

commit_message:
Permit cache-url to work with fifos.

This makes it easier to work with temporary files - less traps
scattered around higher layer code.

Change-Id: I2fdd93115a7b0d289c2e28f8c133d4059de75b87
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/diskimage-builder refs/changes/24/85224/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: type=$(stat $2 -L --printf "%F")if [ "fifo" = "$type" ]; then tmp=$(mktemp download.XXXXXXXX) else tmp=$(mktemp $(dirname $dest)/.download.XXXXXXXX) fi if [ "fifo" = "$type" ]; then cp $tmp $dest rm $tmp else mv $tmp $dest fi

commit_message:
Added functionality to assign FloatingIP addresses

The Instance class got an boolean field 'assignFloatingIp', false by default.
If this is set 'true', the instance will attempt to assign a floating ip in one
of its networks (starting from default ones)

NetworkExplorer class got a functionality to dicover the ID of the external network:
- for newly created networks it will use their specified external router's external_gateway_info
- for existing networks it will iterate among all their routers

Change-Id: I754cd41ffacbf2a2ec62ac23c3a5a7883d1e13b5
Closes-Bug: #1314193
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/murano refs/changes/42/91042/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # noinspection PyPep8Naming def getExternalNetworkIdForRouter(self, routerId): router = self._neutron.show_router(routerId).get('router') if not router or 'external_gateway_info' not in router: return None return router['external_gateway_info'].get('network_id') # noinspection PyPep8Naming def getExternalNetworkIdForNetwork(self, networkId): network = self._neutron.show_network(networkId).get('network') if network.get('router:external', False): return networkId # Get router interfaces of the network router_ports = self._neutron.list_ports( **{'device_owner': 'network:router_interface', 'network_id': networkId}).get('ports') # For each router this network is connected to # check if the router has external_gateway set for router_port in router_ports: ext_net_id = self.getExternalNetworkIdForRouter( router_port.get('device_id')) if ext_net_id: return ext_net_id return None

subject: Fix error: "Stack already exists" in trigger workflow
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-23 21:12:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/solum/commit/0d68a199eef591afa194914897d156e7db34c7a5', 'message': 'Fix error: "Stack already exists" in trigger workflow

On git push, the trigger workflow gets called.
It then then calls the deployer service which currently
tries to redeploy the assembly by creating a new heat
stack instead of updating the existing one. This
results in "Stack already exists" error.

The deployer code should first check if the stack for
the assembly already exists. If yes, it should update
the stack, else it should create a new stack.

Fixes bug 1311275

Change-Id: I2d4810361c1b63db0a17168331114cf17c832bd9

commit_message:
Fix error: "Stack already exists" in trigger workflow

On git push, the trigger workflow gets called.
It then then calls the deployer service which currently
tries to redeploy the assembly by creating a new heat
stack instead of updating the existing one. This
results in "Stack already exists" error.

The deployer code should first check if the stack for
the assembly already exists. If yes, it should update
the stack, else it should create a new stack.

Fixes bug 1311275

Change-Id: I2d4810361c1b63db0a17168331114cf17c832bd9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/solum refs/changes/35/89935/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import re stack_id = self._find_id_if_stack_exists(osc, assem.name) if stack_id is not None: created_stack = osc.heat().stacks.update(stack_id, stack_name=assem.name, template=template, parameters=parameters) else: created_stack = osc.heat().stacks.create(stack_name=assem.name, template=template, parameters=parameters) stack_id = created_stack['stack']['id'] comp_description = 'Heat Stack %s' % ( yaml.load(template).get('description')) objects.registry.Component.assign_and_create(ctxt, assem, 'Heat Stack', comp_description, created_stack['stack'] ['links'][0]['href']) def _find_id_if_stack_exists(self, osc, stack_name): stack_list = osc.heat().stacks.list() for stack in stack_list: if re.match(stack_name, stack.identifier): return stack.identifier.split('/')[-1] return None
deleted_lines: created_stack = osc.heat().stacks.create(stack_name=assem.name, template=template, parameters=parameters) stack_id = created_stack['stack']['id'] comp_description = 'Heat Stack %s' % ( yaml.load(template).get('description')) objects.registry.Component.assign_and_create(ctxt, assem, 'Heat Stack', comp_description, created_stack['stack'] ['links'][0]['href'])

commit_message:
Repair mysql root password configuration

I had to move mysql login and password to /etc/my.cnf
because mysql client could not get passsword from
~.my.cnf when ran by Puppet for some reason.

There is also a separate class mysql::password to
create this file for both plain mysql setup and Galera

Change-Id: I9a9f2a2f479ee7c4b9457329856eabffb1d2b169
Closes-bug: 1297848

commit_message:
Fix collectors and dependencies for ostf-init and Postgre::Db

* Put Exec[ostf-init] after its definition instead of before
* Use -> instead of before/require (should not be used ot once)
* Fix case 'dev' logic by moving collection to the appropriate place

Closes-bug: #1314165

Change-Id: Ib1b4f14bd24594c6a506450c436baf64ff39b74d
Signed-off-by: Bogdan Dobrelya <bdobrelia@mirantis.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/94/90994/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: Postgresql::Db[$dbname] -> Exec['ostf-init'] require => [ Package["fuel-ostf"], File["/etc/ostf/ostf.conf"], ], before => Class['nailgun::supervisor'], }

commit_message:
Fix galera stomping on boot-stack initialization

The mysql-init script mistakenly uses the same initialization singleton
file as reset-db in boot-stack. This causes the portion of reset-db
which starts the mysql service to not be run.

Change-Id: Id0949cd6e360962432e022e084433facf0dff8ab
Closes-bug: #1306596
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-image-elements refs/changes/51/91151/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: MYSQL_INITIALIZED="/mnt/state/var/lib/mysql/galera.initialized"

commit_message:
Add a example that activates a future when a result is ready

To allow for an engine to continue to run while at the same time
returning from a function when a component of that engine finishes
a pattern can be used that ties and engines listeners to the function
return, allowing for both to be used simulatenously.

Change-Id: Iab49e0c7b233138bc2d02247ab7aa3d99a82cd67
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/taskflow refs/changes/47/90247/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # -*- coding: utf-8 -*- # Copyright (C) 2014 Yahoo! Inc. All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. import logging import os import sys from concurrent import futures logging.basicConfig(level=logging.ERROR) self_dir = os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(__file__)) top_dir = os.path.abspath(os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), os.pardir, os.pardir)) sys.path.insert(0, top_dir) sys.path.insert(0, self_dir) # INTRO: in this example linear_flow we will attach a listener to an engine # and delay the return from a function until after the result of a task has # occured in that engine. The engine will continue running (in the background) # while the function will have returned. import taskflow.engines from taskflow.listeners import base from taskflow.patterns import linear_flow as lf from taskflow import states from taskflow import task from taskflow.utils import misc class PokeFutureListener(base.ListenerBase): def __init__(self, engine, future, task_name): super(PokeFutureListener, self).__init__( engine, task_listen_for=(misc.Notifier.ANY,), flow_listen_for=[]) self._future = future self._task_name = task_name def _task_receiver(self, state, details): if state in (states.SUCCESS, states.FAILURE): if details.get('task_name') == self._task_name: if state == states.SUCCESS: self._future.set_result(details['result']) else: failure = details['result'] self._future.set_exception(failure.exception) class Hi(task.Task): def execute(self): # raise IOError("I broken") return 'hi' class Bye(task.Task): def execute(self): return 'bye' def return_from_flow(pool): wf = lf.Flow("root").add(Hi("hi"), Bye("bye")) eng = taskflow.engines.load(wf, engine_conf='serial') f = futures.Future() watcher = PokeFutureListener(eng, f, 'hi') watcher.register() pool.submit(eng.run) return (eng, f.result()) with futures.ThreadPoolExecutor(1) as pool: engine, hi_result = return_from_flow(pool) print(hi_result) print(engine.storage.get_flow_state())

commit_message:
Make the admonition to only run _testenv once more explicit.

Many people, on their second time running through the devtest_*.sh
scripts following the instructions in devtest.html, seem to
misunderstand the instructions about only running _testenv.sh once.

To try to make this clearer, I've modified the language a little and put
it into a "warning" box.

Change-Id: I4fe24bb944d95fa348cb90702beffe4811c8e497
Closes-bug: 1294083
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-incubator refs/changes/54/90854/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ## #. See :doc:`devtest_testenv` for documentation. This step creates the ## seed VM, as well as 4 "baremetal" VMs for the under/overclouds. Details ## of the created VMs are written to ``$TE_DATAFILE``. ## .. warning:: ## You only need to run this step once, the first time you're setting ## up your environment. Unless you remove the VMs and need to recreate ## them, you should skip this step on subsequent runs. Running this ## script with existing VMs will result in information about the existing ## nodes being removed from ``$TE_DATAFILE``
deleted_lines: ## #. See :doc:`devtest_testenv` for documentation. Note that you can make ## your test environment just once and reuse it thereafter. ## TE_DATAFILE should specify where you want your test environment JSON ## file created. (A default value is set in devtest_variables.sh).

Added Devstack integration

- added devstack integration files
- added a simple api test (for the devstack-gate job)

Partial implements blueprint mistral-devstack-gate-job

Change-Id: Ibb859c5eda7719d0e046bf833a6eec69bcbeb8be
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/mistral refs/changes/81/90981/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # 70-mistral.sh - DevStack extras script to install Mistral if is_service_enabled mistral; then if [[ "$1" == "source" ]]; then # Initial source source $TOP_DIR/lib/mistral elif [[ "$1" == "stack" && "$2" == "install" ]]; then echo_summary "Installing mistral" install_mistral elif [[ "$1" == "stack" && "$2" == "post-config" ]]; then echo_summary "Configuring mistral" configure_mistral create_mistral_accounts elif [[ "$1" == "stack" && "$2" == "extra" ]]; then echo_summary "Initializing mistral" init_mistral start_mistral fi if [[ "$1" == "unstack" ]]; then stop_mistral fi fi

commit_message:
Sleep between object ZBF process forks

We've found that, on fresh systems where the ZBF run completes
almost instantaneously, the Swift logs (syslog by default) get
filled-up with object ZBF scan start and completion messages.
This patch calls self._sleep() between ZBF scan runs to cut-down
on these messages and the related unnecessary ZBF scan runs
without impacting the integrity of the object auditing process.

Change-Id: I057c5ca235467cfa115a7a3d44e21c350900059a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/37/91037/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # sleep between ZBF scanner forks self._sleep()

Build os-cloud-config in setup-clienttools

os-cloud-config is going to start including CLI scripts that
devtest will start calling. Install os-cloud-config into the
openstack-tools venv so that scripts are installed.

commit_message:
Limit psutil to <2.0.0

The psutil package recently released psutil version 2.0.0.  This version
made a significant number of changes that are not backwards-compatible.
We should thus restrict the OpenStack psutil requirement to <2.0.0 until
we can ensure that our code is compatible with the new API and that the
2.0.0 version of psutil has had time to propogate to the various
distros.

Needed by: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/78793/
Change-Id: I63d01235a949cd10ba87d41ad428818daaf9a756
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/requirements refs/changes/73/81373/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Let lib/tempest restore errexit setting
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-18 07:05:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/14af411abf5f7c6ba701fd2011a86442b27dea36', 'message': 'Let lib/tempest restore errexit setting

If errexit is on, lib/tempest currently fails to restore it after
turning it off.

lib/tempest uses this code to save the current setting for errexit and
restore it later on:

errexit=$(set +o | grep errexit)

This mechanism works works for other settings, such as xtrace, but for
errexit it returns "set +o errexit" even if errexit is on.

Confirmed for:
bash 4.2.25, Ubuntu 12.04.4 LTS (precise)
bash 4.2.37, Debian 7.4 (wheezy)
bash 4.2.45, Fedora 20 (Heisenbug)

Change-Id: Ia477e04567046a7fcdedf699423165bc577b72ad
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2014-04-24 13:22:13.000000000', 'files': ['lib/tempest'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/b3103d757f165c0dbadf83a67daa8212a6de7ef3', 'message': 'Let lib/tempest restore errexit setting

If errexit is on, lib/tempest currently fails to restore it after
turning it off.

If tempest is enabled, this affects code running after 80-tempest.sh in
"Phase: extra", "Local Configuration", and "Run local script" (after
that, "Fin" disables errexit unconditionally).

lib/tempest uses this code to save the current setting for errexit and
restore it later on:

errexit=$(set +o | grep errexit)

This mechanism works works for other settings, such as xtrace, but for
errexit it returns "set +o errexit" even if errexit is on.

Change-Id: Ia477e04567046a7fcdedf699423165bc577b72ad
'}]
commit_message:
Let lib/tempest restore errexit setting

If errexit is on, lib/tempest currently fails to restore it after
turning it off.

If tempest is enabled, this affects code running after 80-tempest.sh in
"Phase: extra", "Local Configuration", and "Run local script" (after
that, "Fin" disables errexit unconditionally).

lib/tempest uses this code to save the current setting for errexit and
restore it later on:

errexit=$(set +o | grep errexit)

This mechanism works works for other settings, such as xtrace, but for
errexit it returns "set +o errexit" even if errexit is on.

Change-Id: Ia477e04567046a7fcdedf699423165bc577b72ad
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/21/88521/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: local lastpipe # $(set +o | grep errexit) returns "set +o errexit" regardless of setting. lastpipe=$(shopt -p|grep lastpipe) shopt -s lastpipe { set +o|grep errexit; } | read errexit $lastpipe

subject: netaddr<=0.7.10 raises ValueError instead of AddrFormatError
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2014-04-16 18:58:58.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/4c38a9e5fc9c546487304a98b20974a7f2ca4866', 'message': 'netaddr<=0.7.10 raises ValueError instead of AddrFormatError

This patch ensures that ValueError is also caught in addition to

commit_message:
netaddr<=0.7.10 raises ValueError instead of AddrFormatError

This patch ensures that ValueError is also caught in addition to
AddrFormatError as in netaddr>=0.7.11 AddrFormatError is raised and
in netaddr<=0.7.10 ValueError is raised.

Change-Id: I595c90e42129a2d365f3860e3042e826bd031365
Closes-bug: #1308675
(cherry picked from commit dd2ccd12adfb6c7d4aa500ba4120f767beeed35c)

In case the network is without a subnet, calling the validation
logic during the report phase leads to an error because the LSN
would have been already allocated during the migration phase.

Bypass the issue by calling the plugin directly, which is what

commit_message:
NSX: fix migration for networks without a subnet

In case the network is without a subnet, calling the validation
logic during the report phase leads to an error because the LSN
would have been already allocated during the migration phase.

Bypass the issue by calling the plugin directly, which is what
the validation logic does in the first place.

Closes-bug: #1313997

Change-Id: I14f77ae3b0cc147c4ea1c79e56bdd809de7c76a0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/79/90879/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: subnet = self.validate(context, network_id) if subnet: context, network_id, subnet['id'], raise_on_err=False)

Add log_reverse_sort option to drive-audit

Add log_reverse_sort option to drive-audit to support for log files
rotated in "dateext" format

Add a new driver ManagementInterface for management related actions,
the new interface contains the following methods:

* set_boot_device() - To set the boot device for a node.

* get_boot_device() - To get the current boot device of a node.

* get_supported_boot_devices() - To get a list of the supported boot
  devices by that driver.

A new file common/boot_devices.py which contains the standardized names
for the acceptable boot devices, the names are based on the IPMITool
names (the default power driver). The idea is that clients won't need to
know the specific boot device names for each driver, drivers which have
different name options than the IPMITool have to translate it internally.

As part of the work to add tests to the FakeManagement interface, other
tests in test_fake.py were modified in order to remove the DB calls.

commit_message:
Add ManagementInterface

Add a new driver ManagementInterface for management related actions,
the new interface contains the following methods:

* validate() - To validate driver-specific management information. (E.g
  if the node has the right credentials already set)

* set_boot_device() - To set the boot device for a node.

* get_boot_device() - To get the current boot device of a node.

* get_supported_boot_devices() - To get a list of the supported boot
  devices by that driver.

A new file common/boot_devices.py which contains the standardized names
for the acceptable boot devices, the names are based on the IPMITool
names (the default power driver). The idea is that clients won't need to
know the specific boot device names for each driver, drivers which have
different name options than the IPMITool have to translate it internally.

As part of the work to add tests to the FakeManagement interface, other
tests in test_fake.py were modified in order to remove the DB calls.

blueprint: promote-set-boot-device
Change-Id: If2e8074f2e0fbcf962d224024347a0319ac174cf

commit_message:
Validate CIDR given as ip-prefix in security-group-rule-create

There was no validation for the provided ip prefix. This just adds
a simple parse using netaddr and explodes with appropriate message.
Also makes sure ip prefix _is_ cidr (192.168.1.1-->192.168.1.1/32).

Validation occurs at the attribute level (API model) as well as at
the db level, where the ethertype is validated against the ip_prefix
address type.

Unit test cases added - bad prefix, unmasked prefix and incorrect
ethertype. Also adds attribute test cases for the added
convert_ip_prefix_to_cidr method

Closes-Bug: 1255338

Conflicts:
	neutron/tests/unit/test_security_groups_rpc.py
	neutron/tests/unit/test_extension_security_group.py

Change-Id: I71fb8c887963a122a5bd8cfdda800026c1cd3954
(cherry picked from commit 65aa92b0348b7ab8413f359b00825610cdf66607)

commit_message:
Work around atexit bug in python < 2.7.4

In python < 2.7.4, a lazy loading of package `pbr` will break
setuptools if some other modules registered functions in `atexit`.
solution from: http://bugs.python.org/issue15881#msg170215

This problem originally appeared in stevedore
before the library was adopted by Oslo
(https://github.com/dreamhost/stevedore/commit/74a719b11781cc93d60cff1b0a01de3e4e780a1d)

This change places the fix from Icd412ca8435dca4b0f3b4075eca39b903dde6d27
in the right location to be synced into the other repositories.

Change-Id: I7560e474e68bf361f3af61bdfc8e2dbc9e2413f1

commit_message:
Hide the snapshoting instance when attach volume

Hide the instance if instance's task status is not None
when attach volume. (for example,When instance is snapshoting,
we can also see this instance in volume attach page. If attach
volume to this instance, it report error.)

Change-Id: Iba6998ae125424d189defe948a62ed3da6e97d52
Closes-bug:#1308358

commit_message:
Use 127.0.0.1 in mysql connection url

Substituted localhost with 127.0.0.1.

By default, systems with selinux enabled do not allow socket based
connections to mysql. Socket based connections are used when
localhost is in the mysql connection url.

Change-Id: Ic65dc9a58f2a8909b371ef5718b0693df9e6054e

commit_message:
Unit test for common.utils.cache_from_env

The behavior of common.utils.cache_from_env
was changed by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/89488/.
This patch adds unit test for that function.

Change-Id: If757e12990c971325f7705731ef529a7e2a9eee7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/80/90380/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def test_cache_from_env(self): # should never get logging when swift.cache is found env = {'swift.cache': 42} logger = FakeLogger() with mock.patch('swift.common.utils.logging', logger): self.assertEqual(42, utils.cache_from_env(env)) self.assertEqual(0, len(logger.get_lines_for_level('error'))) logger = FakeLogger() with mock.patch('swift.common.utils.logging', logger): self.assertEqual(42, utils.cache_from_env(env, False)) self.assertEqual(0, len(logger.get_lines_for_level('error'))) logger = FakeLogger() with mock.patch('swift.common.utils.logging', logger): self.assertEqual(42, utils.cache_from_env(env, True)) self.assertEqual(0, len(logger.get_lines_for_level('error'))) # check allow_none controls logging when swift.cache is not found err_msg = 'ERROR: swift.cache could not be found in env!' env = {} logger = FakeLogger() with mock.patch('swift.common.utils.logging', logger): self.assertEqual(None, utils.cache_from_env(env)) self.assertTrue(err_msg in logger.get_lines_for_level('error')) logger = FakeLogger() with mock.patch('swift.common.utils.logging', logger): self.assertEqual(None, utils.cache_from_env(env, False)) self.assertTrue(err_msg in logger.get_lines_for_level('error')) logger = FakeLogger() with mock.patch('swift.common.utils.logging', logger): self.assertEqual(None, utils.cache_from_env(env, True)) self.assertEqual(0, len(logger.get_lines_for_level('error')))

'}, {'number': 4, 'created': '2014-01-20 04:17:01.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/e5ea866492316cdda84c79eae7d93891813ea1a0', 'message': 'In-process swift server for functional tests

This patch changes the behavior of the functional tests such that when
both /etc/swift/swift.conf and /etc/swift/test.conf are _not_ present
on the system where the functional tests are executed, an in-process
functioning swift environement will be established, akin to the one
used in test/unit/proxy/test_server.py, and all the functional tests
will be executed against it.

This then allows one to use the coverage options to see how well
functional tests exercise code paths, or more easily debug existing
functional tests or write new ones.

Change-Id: I5acd65e3068868d6509feae1d1954237d37fad45

'}, {'number': 11, 'created': '2014-03-16 04:21:11.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/e3112d9eaef6eb0f0297026e6f3e7d1abf49e028', 'message': 'In-process swift server for functional tests

Provide a way to run the functional tests using a p/a/c/o server setup
in the same process.

By setting the environment variable, SWIFT_TEST_IN_PROCESS, the
functional test set up will construct a proxy, account, container and
object server running in the same process as is running the functional
tests, ignoring any external swift service.

This patch also changes the behavior of the functional tests such that
when both /etc/swift/swift.conf and /etc/swift/test.conf are _not_
present on the system where the functional tests are executing, an
in-process functioning swift environement will be established, akin to
the one used in test/unit/proxy/test_server.py, and all the functional
tests will be executed against it.

Previously, if no /etc/swift/swift.conf and /etc/swift/test.conf files
were found, the tests would just be marked as skipped.

Using this in-process method allows one to gather code coverage using
the functional tests to exercise code paths, in addition to the unit
tests, or more easily debug existing functional tests or write new
ones.

Change-Id: I5acd65e3068868d6509feae1d1954237d37fad45
'}, {'number': 12, 'created': '2014-03-25 21:30:51.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/442100a49d695c83f81ce7588c59800b930016ba', 'message': 'In-process swift server for functional tests

Change-Id: I5acd65e3068868d6509feae1d1954237d37fad45

'}, {'number': 15, 'created': '2014-04-08 00:54:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/e4803fc340431b794fdd8440c86753c5546eab2d', 'message': 'In-process swift server for functional tests

Provide a way to run the functional tests using a p/a/c/o server setup
in the same process running the nosetests infrastructure.

By setting the environment variable, SWIFT_TEST_IN_PROCESS, to a true
value, the functional test set up will construct a proxy, account,
container and object server running in the same process that is running
the functional tests, ignoring any external swift service. This
in-process swift environment is akin to the one used in
test/unit/proxy/test_server.py.

Setting that same environment variable to a false value will ensure the
in-process servers are not used.

When the environment variable is not present, and both
/etc/swift/swift.conf and /etc/swift/test.conf are _not_ present on the
system where the functional tests are executing the in-process
environment will be used. Previously, if no /etc/swift/swift.conf and
/etc/swift/test.conf files were found, the tests would just be marked as
skipped.

Using this in-process method allows one to gather code coverage using
the functional tests to exercise code paths, in addition to the unit
tests, or more easily debug existing functional tests, or write new
ones.

The are two constraints that are changed for use with the in-process
functional tests: max_file_size is lower to roughly 8 MB and
client_timeout is set to 2s.

Change-Id: I5acd65e3068868d6509feae1d1954237d37fad45

'}, {'number': 18, 'created': '2014-04-11 03:05:47.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/swift/commit/12dc42fb871c0317d4526bf89bd95f655af655c5', 'message': 'In-process swift server for functional tests

Provide a way to run the functional tests using a p/a/c/o server setup
in the same process running the nosetests infrastructure.

By setting the environment variable, SWIFT_TEST_IN_PROCESS, to a true
value, the functional test set up will construct a proxy, account,
container and object server running in the same process that is running
the functional tests, ignoring any external swift service. This
in-process swift environment is akin to the one used in
test/unit/proxy/test_server.py.

Setting that same environment variable to a false value will ensure the
in-process servers are not used.

When the above environment variable is not present, and the
/etc/swift/test.conf is _not_ present (or present but empty) on the
system where the functional tests are executing, the in-process
environment will be used. Previously, if no /etc/swift/test.conf file
was found, the tests would just be marked as skipped.

Using this in-process method allows one to gather code coverage using
the functional tests to exercise code paths, in addition to the unit
tests, or more easily debug existing functional tests, or write new
ones.

The are two constraints that are changed for use with the in-process
functional tests: max_file_size is lower to roughly 8 MB and
client_timeout is set to 4s.

Change-Id: I5acd65e3068868d6509feae1d1954237d37fad45

environment will be used. Previously, if no /etc/swift/test.conf file
was found, the tests would just be marked as skipped.

Using this in-process method allows one to gather code coverage using
the functional tests to exercise code paths, in addition to the unit
tests, or more easily debug existing functional tests, or even write new
ones.

There are two constraints that are changed for use with the in-process
functional tests: max_file_size is lowered to roughly 8 MB, and
client_timeout is set to 4s.

Change-Id: I5acd65e3068868d6509feae1d1954237d37fad45

commit_message:
In-process swift server for functional tests

Provide a way to run the functional tests using a p/a/c/o server setup
in the same process running the nosetests infrastructure.

By setting the environment variable, SWIFT_TEST_IN_PROCESS, to a true
value, the functional test framework will construct a set of proxy,
account, container and object servers running in the same process that
is running the functional tests, ignoring any external swift
service. This in-process swift environment is akin to the one used in
test/unit/proxy/test_server.py.

Setting that same environment variable to a false value will ensure the
in-process servers are not used.

When the above environment variable is not present, and the
/etc/swift/test.conf is _not_ present (or present but empty) on the
system where the functional tests are executing, the in-process
environment will be used. Previously, if no /etc/swift/test.conf file
was found, the tests would just be marked as skipped.

Using this in-process method allows one to gather code coverage using
the functional tests to exercise code paths, in addition to the unit
tests, or more easily debug existing functional tests, or even write new
ones.

There are two constraints that are changed for use with the in-process
functional tests: max_file_size is lowered to roughly 8 MB, and
client_timeout is set to 4s.

Change-Id: I5acd65e3068868d6509feae1d1954237d37fad45
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/08/66108/15 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import sysfrom test.functional import in_process_setup, in_process_teardown swift_test_perm, web_front_end, hack_in_process def setup(): if not hack_in_process: # Short circuit, we are using an external Swift server setup return print >>sys.stderr, "setup: in-process Swift server" in_process_setup() def teardown(): if not hack_in_process: # Short circuit, we are using an external Swift server setup return print >>sys.stderr, "teardown: in-process Swift server" in_process_teardown()

commit_message:
Migration DB_INIT_VERSION in common place

Init version value exists only in migration_helpers. migration_helpers
shouldn't know nothing about migrate repos, primarily because it is
intended for handling of any migrate repo in the project.

Change-Id: I8bceea0cf5eaf8e623efbb39e385b1990eca0a6f
Closes-Bug: #1308593

commit_message:
Redundant unique constraint

federation extension have redundant unique constraint. The unique
constraint is totally useless, as (id, idp_id) columns are
columns of a composite primary key, which is unique by definition.

Change-Id: I93648ab89b26d7e77875a1faa8575a146224232f
Partial-Bug: #1292591

commit_message:
Synced jsonutils from oslo-incubator

The sync includes change that drastically enhances performance on Python
2.6 with fresh simplejson library installed.

The latest commit in oslo-incubator:
- 732bdb6297eb9de81667f7713ebcb1ccc2ee45a7

Change-Id: Ib3dc0b713ed90396919feba018772243b3b9c90f
Closes-Bug: 1314129
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic refs/changes/55/91055/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import sys if sys.version_info < (2, 7): # On Python <= 2.6, json module is not C boosted, so try to use # simplejson module if available try: import simplejson as json except ImportError: import json else: import jsonimport six.moves.xmlrpc_client as xmlrpclib return dict((k, recursive(v)) for k, v in six.iteritems(value)) if isinstance(value, xmlrpclib.DateTime):
deleted_lines: # vim: tabstop=4 shiftwidth=4 softtabstop=4 import json try: import xmlrpclib except ImportError: # NOTE(jd): xmlrpclib is not shipped with Python 3 xmlrpclib = None return dict((k, recursive(v)) for k, v in value.iteritems()) if xmlrpclib and isinstance(value, xmlrpclib.DateTime):
